resources.string: This feature requires permission \"Usage Statistics\", it has to be manually enabled in Settings. \nOpen that Setting page?
When enabled, the rule only applies when both number and content match
The global switch, this app only works when this is turned on, a quick way to temporarily disable all the filters, turn it off when you are waiting for some particular call/message.

When enabled, calls/texts from contacts are always permitted.

- Inclusive:
  Non-contact numbers will be checked by other rules.
  Priority: 10

- Exclusive:
  Non-contact numbers will be blocked.
  Equivalent to Inclusive with a number rule .*.
  Priority: 0

It applies to both calls and SMS messages.

Special characters(+ - spaces) in contact numbers are automagically handled.

Permit if the call is repeated within a period of time, it\'s likely to be urgent rather than spam.

Receiving text message from the same number also counts.

The default setting 1 Time / 5 Min means the second call within 5 minutes will be permitted.

Only applies for calls, not for text messages.

Priority: 10

Corresponding to the \"Repeated Call\" that handles the incoming call/message, this feature handles the outgoing.

If a number has been dialed before, calls from that number will always be permitted, even if it is not in contacts.

The default setting 3 Days means if a number has been made outgoing calls within the past 3 days, any calls from that number will be allowed.

Only applies for calls, not for text messages.

Priority: 10

Any incoming call will pass if any app in the list has been used recently.

A typical use case:
  You just ordered a pizza in PizzaApp, soon they call you to refund because they are closing. That call would pass if PizzaApp is enabled here.

The default setting 5 Min means any call will be permitted if any of these apps has been used within 5 minutes, by \"used\" it means either being activated, deactivated, minimized, or killed.

Only applies for calls, not for text messages.

Priority: 10

These rules apply to the incoming phone number.

Important:
To simplify the regex, + and spaces and leading zeroes are removed before checking, for example:
  The following list covers all the possible formats:
   123456789  (regular number)
   1 2345 6789  (with spaces)
   +12 3456 789  (with leading +)
   012 345 6789  (with domestic trunk prefix 0)
   00123456789  (two 0s)
  They are all checked as:
   123456789
 So regex 1234567.* would match all of them.

The list is displayed in descending order of priority, ascending description, and ascending pattern.

Uncheck the checkboxes to disable the rule, useful for testing.
Swipe left to delete a rule.

These rules apply to the SMS message content.

Note: For SMS messages, this app works as an \"addon\" of the default SMS app, it blocks notifications instead of blocking messages, spam messages will still be present in the default SMS app. Disable the notification of the default SMS app in system settings, let this app take over the notification, otherwise there will be double notifications.

The list is displayed in descending order of priority, ascending description, and ascending pattern.

A quick way to copy content from SMS messages, such as verification codes.

When it matches, a button like Copy: 123456 would appear in the notification.
It\'s not like clicking on the notification, when the copy button is clicked, only this notification is dismissed, other notifications will remain.

A sample rule: (using capturing group)
  code.*?(\\d+)
Another approach: (using lookaround)
  (?<=code.{0,3})\\d+
 Note:
  It doesn\'t support .* in lookarounds, it requires a bounded max length.
  for example, use: (?<=code.{0,3})\\d+
  instead of: (?<=code.*)\\d+

It only works when the SMS message is NOT blocked.
You can uncheck these checkboxes to disable this rule for Call, SMS, or both.

None: No notification at all.
Shade: The dropdown notification shade.
StatusBar: The small icon in the top bar.
Sound: The default notification sound.
Heads-Up: Popups a floating window on the top of the screen.

This helps to check if the rules are set as expected.

It\'s just a simulation and will not actually popup an incoming call(or text message).

The result is shown here, and in history log, with notification.

This is not a simulation, it only shows if any quick-copy rule matches the content.

To simulate receiving, use the Test from Message Rules instead.

To Backup:
  1. Press Export to show the configuration in the textbox.
  2. Press Copy to copy it to clipboard.
  3. Send this configuration text to another device.

To Restore:
  1. Paste the configuration text into the textbox.
  2. Press Import.
   When it fails, try to validate that json text, it may have been corrupted during transfer. If so, send it in a file instead.

History records are ignored.

If some switches like "Contacts" is not enabled after restoring, check the corresponding permission in system settings, permissions are not \"restored\" automatically.

This app does not require INTERNET and STORAGE permissions, there won\'t be feature like \"backup to cloud or storage file\".

These flags change the matching behavior of the regex, they are set for new rules by default. When they are modified, there will be an indicator before the rule text.

Ignore Case:
  It makes the pattern matching case-insensitive, a would match both a and A.

Dot Match All:
  When enabled, . will also match newline characters (\\n), this allows the dot to match across multiple lines.
  Use case:
  Match multiline spam message:
  claim your prize: http://
  abc.com
  with rule:
  *http.*com.*
